title: CVE-2022-35252: control code in cookie denial of service

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

vulnerability_information:
## Summary: I took a look at https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/9048/commits/d7bcbc7d8d4b6d972d3da12d54819169a19c287b (a sneak peek on a vulnerability to be announced tomorrow). My guess for that vulnerability is that since cookies are persistent, someone who can trick curl into storing cookies can store large amounts of cookies into curl cookie store, which will prevent curl from ever interacting with the server (due to large request being generated causing a 400 error) I found a separate way to do this, curl does not implement character check on cookie name or value when saving to cookie store. So for example a form feed '\f' can be saved in curl's cookie store. When form feed is sent by curl to a server such as Apache, Apache will respond with 400 Error (historically, Apache would accept, however now due to HTTP smuggling concerns, Apache will now strictly reject any such control characters.), preventing someone from ever interacting the server with the cookie store. According to the spec, cookies should not contain control characters anyway, see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6265#section-4.1.1. ## Steps To Reproduce: 1. In test.php, ````` GET / HTTP/1.1 > Host: 127.0.0.1 > User-Agent: curl/7.83.1 > Accept: */* > Cookie: a=b > * Mark bundle as not supporting multiuse < HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request < Date: Tue, 21 Jun 2022 04:09:08 GMT < Server: Apache/2.4.43 (Debian) < Content-Length: 301 < Connection: close < Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1 < 400 Bad Request

Bad Request

Your browser sent a request that this server could not understand.

Apache/2.4.43 (Debian) Server at 127.0.1.1 Port 80
````` ## Impact An attacker can possibly MiTM the connection and poison the cookie store using cookies with control characters, preventing a user / application from ever interacting with the particular HTTP server with the same cookie store. Possibly same impact as the "cookie limit" vulnerability to be announced tomorrow.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!

I can reproduce. This seems to be pretty specific to Apache httpd; several other HTTP implementations accept such cookies fine.

The question is perhaps: is forging a cookie content into getting a 400 response a security problem in curl?

The rationale is that it poisons a cookie store and makes it such that a user / application using the same cookie store can no longer communicate with the HTTP server properly (similar to the "Cookie Bomb" attack) effectively causing a DoS. 

I submitted this after reading cookie limit commit. My guess was that this cookie limit was set to prevent the "Cookie Bomb" vulnerability where an attacker essentially puts many cookies into the cookie store to generate a large request and prevent someone from communicating with the server (due to server rejection of large request). But it seems like I was incorrect, I will wait for the official advisory for that one.

Node's HTTP server also will reject the request with Cookie header containing control characters

In fact most servers online will reject any request containing control characters in the header.

Here's my thinking and why I'm not sure how I lean on this issue.

Cookies are known to have  [weak integrity](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-rfc6265bis-10#section-8.6) which allows "sibling domains" (or MITMs) to overflow cookie containers etc so that subsequent requests to the "real" site may not work as intended. A site might return a 403 or similar when this happens. This is something we cannot protect against and is simply due to how cookies work.

You have presented a way how a sibling domain (or MITM) can cause a 400 to be returned. Is this different enough than the 403 case above?

Further: what exactly in the 400 response makes it a DoS? It's not hard to imagine that there are hypothetical servers somewhere in production that verify cookie content before use in more strict ways than the RFC6265 spec, since the server is the one that decides how the cookies should look like. Such a server could very well return a 4xx error when the client sends ill-formatted cookies to it. It would be the server's right to do this, yet we would hardly call that a DoS.

I agree with this being difficult to determine whether this is a security issue or not.

I had based this entirely on https://hackerone.com/reports/1569946. While the report in #1569946 can be said different as it showcases a DoS on the client-side, I would argue that they are both the same, in #1569946 and in this report. Both issues prevent curl from communicating with the server, and only the server which is being attacked (so for example an attacker who controls foo.example.com can prevent curl from communicating with the 2nd level example.com and only those domains, in both #1569946 and this report.) 

A 400 response is generated from the underlying server technology (ie. Apache httpd, nginx) being used, which means that there is nothing the application can do to handle it. If I understand your question correctly, this is different from the other 4XX responses, where I would presume a server which encounters an invalid session_id, would overwrite it.
Deemed a security problem.
Here's my first take a patch. This rejects all cookies with names/contents using octets that are not valid according to the cookie RFC.

I can confirm the patch works.

I also noticed that space (\x20), comma, double quote and backslash are on the list. I've tested on Chrome, and Chrome seems to accept these cookie octets. Perhaps they should removed from the list.

For reference the list here is what Firefox rejects* -> https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/netwerk/cookie/CookieCommons.cpp#202 and https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/netwerk/cookie/CookieCommons.cpp#210

I'm a little conflicted. If we ignore cookies using invalid octets because they are not valid cookies according to the [spec](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-rfc6265bis-10#section-4.1.1) - then shouldn't we assume that all "illegal" bytes can potentially cause this problem? If an http server can respond with 400 for an illegal cookie octet, what stops them from returning 400 for other illegal octets than just the "control bytes" (<0x20) ?

Strictly speaking, I believe Apache httpd at least rejects this request in its normal request reader (due to ctrl bytes) so its not actually cookie-specific, but still.

We should probably take this up as an issue for 6265bis if in fact most implementers support space, command and double-quotes in cookies.
I submitted an issue: https://github.com/httpwg/http-extensions/issues/2185
I think servers will reject all headers containing the control characters (\x00-\x1F), not specifically because of the Cookie header.
Did you check if they usually reject \x09 (TAB) too? The Firefox cookie code allows it.
I presume they don't reject TAB, because if they do it feels like we could reproduce this issue using TAB in cookies with Chrome or Firefox.

When I tested curl cookie parsing, the TAB character would mess up the Netscape file format anyway (due to tab-delimitation), and cause cookies with "tabs" to not be sent, so it isn't relevant there.

Sending a tab to an Apache server in a header also does not cause it to error
````
curl -vv -H $'abc: example\tabc' http://127.0.0.1
````
In Chrome, control characters are rejected in both Set-Cookie and document.cookie including \t.

However, I was indeed able to set control character in Firefox via document.cookie (They only fixed Set-Cookie). I think I will raise this issue with them and see what they say.

I have filed -> https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1777206.

Note: as curl can be used in server-side applications, where a cookie store may be more difficult to clear, I think this issue is generally more severe in curl than the browsers (although I would still rate it as Low severity), where it is possible to clear such cookie store via a click of a button.

> When I tested curl cookie parsing, the TAB character would mess up the Netscape file format anyway (due to tab-delimitation), and cause cookies with "tabs" to not be sent, so it isn't relevant there

Oh right. But if you do cookies in memory, without going through an intermediary file, curl should be able to use and send TABs.
Based on all this, I think we should just probably only ignore cookie octets using 0x01-0x1f but not for 0x09.
Here's the patch version 2.
I left the TAB unfiltered for now.

Patch is missing \x7F, while testing I noticed that Apache rejects the \x7F character in header fields as well.

In Chrome, \x7F is rejected in cookies despite what the Firefox comment says. I think Firefox charset is also missing the \x7F character.
Did you check any bytes >= \x80 ? They are not allowed according to spec.
version 3

Since this issue is not set **high** nor **critical**, we would like to work on this issue, create a detailed security advisory, create a patch and ideally one or two tests and then **go public in sync with the pending next release** (this might then end up as one out of several issues that go public on the same date). We hope this is okay with you, as otherwise we can certainly discuss and maybe work out an expedited schedule.

Right now, the release is scheduled for August 31, 2022.

I can confirm that all problematic bytes are present. Its only 0x01-0x1f (exclude 0x09) + 0x7f.

An extremely hacky one-liner which sends chars \x01-\xff in headers, and prints the bad characters which cause 400 error.  (Warning: execute this in a unused and empty directory as it saves the control characters (in \xNN form) as the file name and iterates through each file to find "400" response code.)
````
for i in {1..255}; do curl -o "\x$(printf %x $i)" -H "a: $(printf "\x$(printf %x $i)")" http://127.0.0.1; done; grep -Rl "400" . | sort
`````

Looks like I referenced the wrong part of the spec, as stated by the GH issue (oops!). The relevant part is https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-rfc6265bis/#section-5.4

In it,
`````
   1.  If the set-cookie-string contains a %x00-08 / %x0A-1F / %x7F
       character (CTL characters excluding HTAB): Abort these steps and
       ignore the set-cookie-string entirely.
`````

(In my defence, the spec is rather confusing as it defines two grammars for server / client. One would assume that the cookie grammar for server also applies to the client. There is currently an open PR which aims to address this: https://github.com/httpwg/http-extensions/pull/1759)

additional_data.old_title: Control character in cookie store (preventing further interaction with server using the same cookie store)
additional_data.new_title: CVE-2022-35252: control code in cookie denial of service

activities.message: First draft of a Security Advisory for this flaw.

Recommendations Part A should be

"Upgrade curl to version 7.85.0"

other than that, lgtm.
Oops, fixed now in my local version.

BTW, [here](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1174647)  is a Chrome bug from Feb 2021 where they add 0x7f to the filter it rejects to avoid "client side DoS". Similar to our issue here, but they already had most of them stripped.
Published. This issue is now eligible for a bounty claim from [IBB](https://hackerone.com/ibb).

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.

Hi @bagder, could you check if the IBB team had contacted you? I did submit the reward request about 1 month ago and the response I had received was that a check process had been initiated without any further response. In any case, I think they contacted you to verify something? Could you check if they did? Thanks a lot!

I have had no contact with anyone on the IBB for a long time, no. I would think they can just email me at daniel@haxx.se if there's anything I can do.

This said, this issue should be crystal clear and should not require any clarifications from me...
